newsitem.title: SOUTH KOREA: S.Korean chipmakers to cut 16-megabit DRAM output.
newsitem.headline: S.Korean chipmakers to cut 16-megabit DRAM output.

text.p: South Korean chipmakers said on Tuesday they planned to temporarily suspend production lines of 16-megabit dynamic random access memory (DRAM) chips for five to eight days and allow workers to take holidays.
The decision was partly in reaction to recent falls in international spot prices for the chips, spokesmen at the chipmakers said.

Samsung Electronics Co plans to halt production lines for a week from July 26, cutting output for the month by about a third, spokesman Raymond Park said. "We will suspend our 16-megabit DRAM lines for seven days and need another two to three days before returning to normal operations," he said.
LG Semicon Co plans to stop production lines for eight days and Hyundai Electronics Industries Co for five days, spokesmen for those two companies said.
The international spot price for 16-megabit DRAM chips has fallen to below $7 per unit these days from this year's peak at over $10 in April, the spokesmen said.
They attributed the recent price drop to traditionally low demand during the summer.
They said South Korean chipmakers were not too worried about weak spot prices because their sales were mostly made in long-term contracts.
"Our long-term contract price is now stable at $8-$9 per unit, compared with this year's peak at around $10 in April," said LG Semicon spokesman Han Dong-mun.
